Census 2010 demographic data available through MARPLOT.  A single worst case flammable and toxic scenario was documented in the RMP*eSubmit 
7.2.	ALTERNATIVE CASE   (C) (2)
The alternative release scenario involves the failure of a hose, pipes/valves of each system.  This failure was defined during the 2010 and 2014 Process Hazards Analysis.  This failure is equal to creating hole in the hose, a pipe, or even the container itself.  Modeling using the EPA/RMP Comp and EPA's guidance demonstrated the rate of highly hazardous chemical release is 100.0 lb. per minute for a period of 60 minutes releasing a total of 6,000 pounds of chemical.  The toxic endpoint distances determined is listed in the process safety information.  The residential population that would be impacted by this release is recorded in the process safety information.  Environmental receptors in this area were also identified.  Each alternative case scenario was entered in the RMP*eSubmit.

nursing homes were identified.  The hazard assessment considers two release scenarios a worst case and an alternative case, and also compiles the five-year accident history for all highly hazardous chemical system.
The first scenario is a worst case release.  The second is a more probable alternative release scenario.  The first scenario is defined by EPA, which states that the operator shall assume that the maximum quantity in the largest vessel is released over 10 minutes due to an unspecified failure.  The alternative scenario is defined as more likely to occur than the worst-case scenario.
Atmospheric dispersion modeling was performed to determine the distance traveled by the highly hazardous chemical released before its concentration decreases to the toxic endpoint.  The EPA specified endpoint for highly hazardous chemical is the Emergency Response Planning Guideline Level 2 (ERPG-2).  This is defined by the American Industrial Hygiene Association (AIHA) as the maximum airborne concentration below which it is believed that nearly all individuals could be exposed for up to one hour without experiencing or developing irreversible or other serious health effects or symptoms which could impair an individual's ability to take protective action.  The residential population within a circle with a radius corresponding to the toxic endpoint distance was defined, to estimate the population potentially affected.
7.1.	WORST CASE   (C) (1)
Atmospheric dispersion modeling for the worst-case scenario was performed using the EPA assumptions and EPA's RMP Comp Program.  Results demonstrate a distance to the toxic endpoint for each RMP chemical and are listed in the plant's Process Safety Information (PSI).  The program also lists the miles of area assuming an urban topography without an enclosure.  The residential population that could potentially be affected by each release..  Also the environmental and public receptors were identified based on the    U. S.

in:
5.1.1.	Development of the operation procedures
5.1.2.	Hazard evaluations 
5.1.3.	On-going training of the operators and other involved staff
5.1.4.	Process Hazards Analysis (PHA) work group
5.1.5.	PSM/RMP safety teams / first responders
5.1.6.	Accident Incident investigation Team

6.	PLANNED CHANGES TO IMPROVE SAFETY (G)
Changes to improve safety (recommended actions) were identified in the Process Hazards Analysis conducted in September 2022 using the What if method.  Other recommended actions have recently been completed based on the 2022 PHA and compliance audit as directed by the RMP program to meet requirements and make the plant safer.  The 2022 PHA recommended actions include action items that have been evaluated and are in the process of being resolved as required.  An internal compliance audit was conducted in Nov 2023 of the PSM and RMP program.  Key safety action items were completed.  
Clean Harbors continually develops new and reviews implemented operating procedures for potential safety improvements for all of its operations.  Currently, the Clean Harbors plant management team and process safety team are reviewing potential upgrades to the existing design of the hazardous waste chemical operations to make the system even safer to prevent a release and minimize consequences in the event of a release of any hazardous chemicals including all RMP HHCs.  

7.	HAZARD ASSESSMENT
(Note:  This section is not required.  However, on overview of our hazard assessment follows, minus the results that are documented in our PSI.)
A hazard assessment was performed to determine the effects a release would have on the plant, environment and the public. For each RMP chemical, the distance to each endpoint concentration of each toxic would travel was determined.  In addition, an estimate of the population within the radius endpoint that could be affected by a release of highly hazardous chemical was determined, and sensitive receptors such as hospitals, schools, and

operation and response procedures are also reviewed annually.
The emergency response program (contingency plan) is coordinated (reviewed by) with the plant Safety Committee.  The plant coordinates with local Harris County, Deer Park Local Response Planning Committee (LEPC) and County HazMat Team.  All are located in the Harris County, Deer Park area.  Copies of the program are given to key local agencies including: fire, medical, rescue, and police departments.  Besides the specific emergency response program, key elements of the prevention programs are incorporated in the operating culture of the Clean Harbors plant.  All employees who work with hazardous waste receive initial and annual HazWopper training as well as all required RMP training.
The Contingency Plan/Emergency Response Plan procedures detail the actions and responses to highly hazardous chemical spills (releases).  The plan includes training of all facility operators and maintenance staff.  The primary response team includes our trained certified employees, the Harris County, Deer Park Harris County Fire and Rescue, and county HazMat Teams.  All of these respond to any severe highly hazardous chemical leak situation.  Actions include catastrophic, severe, and moderate leaks.  A highly hazardous chemical A as well as B Leak Repair Kit is maintained  near the chemical storage area to aid in stopping leaks of cylinders and containers.  Public notification is facilitated through the County Police and Sheriff's Office, which has an automated emergency dialing message system for public notification.

5.1.	PERSONNEL (F) (1)
Personnel are the key resource of the Clean Harbors' prevention program.  Plant employees make up the administrative, maintenance, operators and emergency operations first responders (consisting of managers, maintenance and operations staff).  The Clean Harbors fosters a high level of involvement in every aspect of the highly hazardous chemical system operations including participation

tankers, fixed vessels and shipment containers.  Many containers are stored in the warehouse system of buildings. The plant and support equipment of the bulk liquid and waste chemical storage buildings and meet and exceed design codes standards and good engineering practices.  The control room building is equipped with a forced ventilation system and can be used for sheltering in place.  There is a closed circuit television system to enable operators to monitor the control room building.  The control room has a highly hazardous chemical monitor.  Detection monitors alarm in their local area as well as in the Clean Harbors plant control room. 
Fire sprinklers, deluge, monitor and extinguishers are installed throughout the plant.  These are inspected and kept in good operation condition.
3.2.4.	Equipment Design
There are two types of hazardous waste chemical storage systems: high pressure and low pressure.  Both systems design, construction and maintenance meet or exceed standards for the various chemicals as recommended by manufacturers, NFPA, NEC, etc.   All containers and piping systems are made of chemical compatible steel, alloy or non-metallic compounds. 

4.	FIVE-YEAR ACCIDENT HISTORY (E)
The plant has been RMP reportable accident free for listed chemicals above the threshold quantity in the past five years.  Our accident incident policy requires that a team investigate each accident, illness, incident or near miss accident within 48 hour for all incidents including PSM or RMP chemicals per plant policy.
5.	EMERGENCY RESPONSE PROGRAM (F)
Emergency response procedures contained in the Plant Emergency Response Policy are coordinated with the Harris County Contingency Plan (Emergency Response Plan).  The plan includes an emergency response decision tree and a notification plan.  The Plant also has site specific emergency actions defined in the plant's operating procedures.  Emergency response drills are conducted annually by the operating department.  Emergency

for all operations making mechanical integrity a part of each piece of equipment. 
Incident investigations of accidents and near-miss incidents for all operations, including RMP covered areas, ensure we learn from each event as well as correct the causes of the incident.  This is conducted by a team and results are provided to our staff.
Employees participate in all aspects of the plant as listed below under emergency response. 
Safe work practices are used throughout the facility including:  1) Hot Work Permits, 2) Lock Out Tag Out Permits, 3) Vessel Entry Permits, 4) Site Security, and 5) Breaking Into Chemical Lines. 
Contractors must meet Clean Harbors' high safety and technical standards as part of selection and ongoing evaluations.  Also, Clean Harbors demands training of contractors to our standards. 
3.2.	HIGHLY HAZARDOUS CHEMICAL SPECIFIC RESPONSE PROGRAM (D) (2)
3.2.1.	Chemical-Specific Operating Safety Information
Chemical-specific prevention features of the plant include: the policies and procedures listed above and those of the highly hazardous chemical specific program.  These include:
3.2.2.	Specific procedures for the management of the highly hazardous chemical process. 
Completion of a Pre-startup Safety Review prior to startup of the modified highly hazardous chemical system.   
Specific emergency response procedures for highly hazardous chemical releases as outlined below under both operating procedures and in the emergency response procedures.   See the Emergency Response Program 
Specific training in the properties, hazards, handling requirements, and leak repair for highly hazardous chemical is conducted annually.
Individual procedures of various hazardous waste stream operators include offloading, storage, direct burning, etc. 
Finally, the details of both facility and equipment design are key to the safe operations of the highly hazardous chemical system.
3.2.3.	Facility Design
The hazardous waste chemical storage area is housed in delivery

ess safeguards employed have been provided to the regulatory agencies. 
The facility is making a predictive filing as these chemicals may be on site over the threshold level.  However, typically inventories of regulated high hazard flammable and toxic chemicals are routinely maintained below the threshold quantities. The Clean Harbors, Deer Park, Treatment Storage and Disposal Plant employ 267 full-time employees.

3.	ACCIDENTAL RELEASE PREVENTION PROGRAM (D)
The Clean Harbors accidental release prevention program is based on Good Engineering Practices, OSHA's PSM program and EPA's RMP Level 3 prevention program.  The PSM/RMP program has been in place and effectively used for many years.  It is part of the plants operating culture.  There are two parts to the program.  The first is the general overall Clean Harbors division wide program and the Clean Harbors Treatment Plant site-specific program.  This is coordinated with the Harris County, Deer Park LEPC, and the County Fire/Rescue Department (including the HazMat Team).
3.1.	GENERAL ACCIDENTAL RELEASE PREVENTION PROGRAM   (D) (1)
Plant-wide, many elements of the prevention program are used for all operations.  An overview of the generally written programs is listed below:
Clean Harbors has detailed process safety information on each of its operations.  Also a chemical profile is required for each waste stream that is received at the facility.  This profile lists the maximum concentration of each constituent.  The profile is used in the daily evaluation of the quantity of all PSM and RMP chemicals on site.
Our document maintenance system is integral to the management of change for all PSM/RMP operations on site.
Training is the backbone of employee knowledge, job operations and is ongoing in each area.  Employee training in operations and maintenance emphas awareness of the hazardous and toxic properties of all chemicals used.
Refresher training is conducted annually.
Maintenance and preventive maintenance are used

by OSHA's Process Safety Management Program (PSM).  
Ethyl Ether (a flammable chemical has been added to our list of covered RMP chemicals for this submission.

As a hazardous waste facility permitted under the Resource Conservation and Recovery Act and the Clean Air Act, extensive documentation of materials handled and proc

(B) (1)	
The site is owned and operated by The Clean Harbors Environmental Services. The location is 2027 Independence Parkway South, La Porte, Harris County, Texas 77571.  The location of one of the tank truck chemical off-loading operations within the plant is Lat 29.731303, Long -95.095424 and our EPA ID number is: 100000059107.
The boundaries of the highly hazardous chemical system subject to the RMP regulation include the bulk rail car off-loading area, the tank truck off-loading area; both are adjacent to the tank farm used to store these chemicals.  There is also a bulk direct burn area that can handle several tank truck trailers at a time as well as three Glove Box areas use to direct burn drums, cylinders, and tote bins of various hazardous chemicals.  The plant also has a large warehouse area for storage of containerized hazardous chemicals.  Standard containers vary from lab pack items, one, five, 30, 55 gallon drums and tote bins up to 320 gallon in .  The final boundary of the RMP process is when the material is oxidized in the various combustion chambers of or incineration systems.  All of the systems are detailed in the Process and Instrument Drawings (P&ID) which are part of the plant Process Safety Information (PSI).  All drawings are maintained in the plants RMP PSI files.  Feeding of the kiln is directed by the operations group from a central control room located between the bulk liquid storage area and the kiln feed areas. 
2.1.1.	Regulated substance (b) (2)
Highly hazardous chemicals including both flammable and toxics may be on site that exceeds the EPA 40 CFR-68 rule's threshold quantities.  The TSD operates under permit from the Texas Commission on Environmental Quality (TCEQ).  Hazardous waste streams include highly hazardous chemicals (HHCs) that are received, stored and disposed of by incineration in Clean Harbors kiln treatment process systems. 
Highly hazardous chemicals are EPA-listed toxic or flammable chemicals. Most are also covered

for the chemicals described below to be present at the plant. 
These chemicals will occasionally be stored at the facility in quantities exceeding the threshold planning quantities. 
All potential HHCs and their RMP maximum intended inventory are listed below in Section #2.  An evaluation of all the PSM and RMP chemicals on site is determined on a daily basis. The daily evaluation is a conservative estimate of the quantity of each chemical.  It's based on the maximum amount of that chemical in each waste stream.  Cooperating local response agencies are informed of the complete predictive RMP list and upon request, the actual facility inventories are provided.  
1.2.	MANAGEMENT SYSTEMS (A) (1)
Clean Harbors has a management system in place which is led by the plant General Manager.  The Clean Harbors Safety Manager and Compliance Manager oversee the execution and on-going implementation of the RMP as well as the like PSM elements.  This program, along with other plant-wide and plant-specific policies, eliminates and/or reduces the likelihood of a hazardous chemical release at the plant.  An organizational chart defining the lines of authority and responsible staff is included in the plant's RMP Process Safety Information and a copy is attached to this RMP*eSubmital.
1.3.	PREVENTION PROGRAM LEVEL 3 (A) (2)
Clean Harbors maintains policies, procedures, systems and staff that are an integral part of our prevention program.  These are applied to each process in our plant operations.  The program addresses each of the EPA Program Level 3-listed 12 elements, needed to implement the program, and the like elements in place in the plants' OSHA PSM program.  These are maintained by the Clean Harbors Treatment Plant Document Management System (DMS).

2.	STATIONARY SOURCE AND REGULATED SUBSTANCES HANDLED (B)  
Clean Harbors operates a treatment storage and disposal hazardous waste incinerator system for the destruction of liquid and solid waste products.  
2.1.	SITE DESCRIPTION

CLEAN HARBORS ENVIRONMENTAL SERVICES
RISK MANAGEMENT PROGRAM 2014 RE-SUBMITTAL
EXECUTIVE SUMMARY per 40 CFR-68.155

INTRODUCTION 68.155

Clean Harbors Environmental Services (Clean Harbors) operates treatment storage disposal (TSD) hazardous waste incinerator systems at our plant.  This plant is one of two sites that Clean Harbors operates in the Deer Park Area.  Clean Harbors has a unified Risk Management Program which applies to TSD plant.  Only the 2027 Independence Parkway South Plant operations and policies are presented in this RMP*eSubmit Plan.

1.	ACCIDENTAL RELEASE PREVENTION/EMERGENCY RESPONSE POLICIES (A)
The Clean Harbors Deer Park Plant accidental release prevention policies involve a unified approach that integrates technologies, equipment, procedures and management practices.  The plant prevention program complies with all applicable requirements of the U.S. Environmental Protection Agency (EPA) Risk Management Program (RMP), 40 CFR-68, Prevention Program under the Clean Air Act Amendments of 1990.  The Plant is also subject to Occupational Safety and Health Act's (OSHA) Process Safety Management Program, (PSM) 29 CFR-1910-119, of Highly Hazardous Chemicals.  The OSHA program is similar to the EPA's RMP prevention program and EPA emergency response program.
Clean Harbors provides for and encourages employees to participate in all facets of PSM and RMP safety and prevention programs as outlined in our Employee Participation policy and procedure.  Clean Harbors also provides a variety of technical documents beyond the RMP and PSM-required policies and procedures.   The documents are used to maintain safe operation of the processes and include chemical handling instructions. 
1.1.	PREDICTIVE FILING (A) (1)
The plant is a treatment storage and disposal site that uses incineration for treatment (destruction) of the hazardous waste streams we are permitted to treat.  Because of the nature of this operation we use predictive filing since there is a potential
